title: How to Wear a Knitted Headband

steps.headline: Straighten or curl your hair as you normally would.
steps.description: The majority of your hair will be hanging down for this look, so style it like you would normally, leaving it loose around your shoulders. You can make soft waves, thick curls, or straighten your hair for this look. You can also braid your hair in 2 pigtails at the back of your head if you’d like to. Make sure the braids hang straight down.

steps.headline: Place the headband over your ears and forehead.
steps.description: Pick your knitted headband up and put it over your head, making sure it touches your forehead and the very bottom of your skull. Position the headband so that it won’t slip off as you wear it throughout the day by keeping it over your ears and on top of your forehead. Keep all of your hair hanging loose underneath the headband. Most knitted headbands are pretty thick, so they shouldn’t slip off. However, a lot of movement throughout the day can sometimes knock them loose.

steps.headline: Use your fingers to rake up some of the hair on the crown of your head.
steps.description: A knitted headband is heavy and it can pull your hair flat against your head. Give yourself some volume by using your fingers to very gently pull some of the hair on top of your head up towards the ceiling. Try not to pull whole strands out and create flyaways. If you accidentally pull too much hair out, take off your headband and put it back on again. This will reset your hair.

steps.headline: Keep an eye on your hair to make sure it doesn’t bunch up on top.
steps.description: Knitted headbands have a tendency to move around and shift which can lead to the top of your hair bunching up and shifting. Bring a compact mirror with you to check on your hair as you wear your headband.Tip: If your hair does bunch up, just take your headband off and put it back on again. This will smooth out any flyaways. You can also spray the top of your hair with a thin layer of hairspray to prevent flyaways.

steps.headline: Separate the hair on the crown of your head with a clip.
steps.description: Pull back the top part of your hair just above your ears like you normally would to put your hair half-up. Put this hair into a loose bun and secure it back with a large hair clip. You can leave some hair hanging over your ears if you’d like to.

steps.headline: Wrap the headband over your forehead and back of your head.
steps.description: Pick up your headband and put it on your head how you normally would with the front over your forehead and the back resting against the base of your skull. Be careful around the hair clip in your hair and try not to disturb anything that’s tied up. Knitted headbands have a tendency to catch on pointy ends. Use caution around your hair clip so that you don’t rip or stretch out your headband.

steps.headline: Let your hair down from the clip.
steps.description: Make sure your hair falls how it naturally would over the back of your head. Use your fingers to separate any clumps of hair that may be there after using the clip. You can also switch out your clip for some bobby pins and leave half of your hair pinned up if you’d prefer.

steps.headline: Adjust your hair until it falls naturally over the headband.
steps.description: Use your fingers or a wide-toothed comb to push your hair forward towards your face over the headband. Use a mirror to look at the back of your head to check for lumps or bumps. This should create a seamless look that hides the back of the headband underneath your hair.Tip: If you did not pull enough hair back with your clip, it may bump out awkwardly over your headband. If it does, just take the headband off and start over with more hair pinned up on top.

steps.headline: Place the headband over your head and around your neck.
steps.description: It’s much easier to complete this look when the headband is already up over your head. Before you touch your hair, pull the headband up and over your head so that it is resting around your neck.

steps.headline: Pull all of your hair up into a ponytail or bun with a hair tie.
steps.description: Use your fingers to rake your hair back to the crown of your head. Secure your hair at the top of your head with a hair tie in a messy bun or a ponytail.Tip: Don’t use a brush to rake back your hair before you put it up. This hairstyle is supposed to look a little bit messy.

steps.headline: Move the headband up over your ears and around the back of your head.
steps.description: Grab the headband from around your neck and scoot it upward until it sits how you would normally wear it. Make sure that your hair is up high enough that it goes over the back of the headband. If your hair isn’t up high enough, you may not be able to see it behind the headband.

steps.headline: Grab some pieces of hair from underneath the headband to frame your face.
steps.description: If you’d like a little bit more face framing, reach up under your headband and grab a few strands of hair in front of your ears on either side. Pull them out from underneath the headband so that they hang down and frame your face. This works well with the “messy” vibe of the overall hairstyle.

text: Leaving Your Hair Loose Straighten or curl your hair as you normally would. The majority of your hair will be hanging down for this look, so style it like you would normally, leaving it loose around your shoulders. You can make soft waves, thick curls, or straighten your hair for this look. You can also braid your hair in 2 pigtails at the back of your head if you’d like to. Make sure the braids hang straight down. Place the headband over your ears and forehead. Pick your knitted headband up and put it over your head, making sure it touches your forehead and the very bottom of your skull. Position the headband so that it won’t slip off as you wear it throughout the day by keeping it over your ears and on top of your forehead. Keep all of your hair hanging loose underneath the headband. Most knitted headbands are pretty thick, so they shouldn’t slip off. However, a lot of movement throughout the day can sometimes knock them loose. Use your fingers to rake up some of the hair on the crown of your head. A knitted headband is heavy and it can pull your hair flat against your head. Give yourself some volume by using your fingers to very gently pull some of the hair on top of your head up towards the ceiling. Try not to pull whole strands out and create flyaways. If you accidentally pull too much hair out, take off your headband and put it back on again. This will reset your hair. Keep an eye on your hair to make sure it doesn’t bunch up on top. Knitted headbands have a tendency to move around and shift which can lead to the top of your hair bunching up and shifting. Bring a compact mirror with you to check on your hair as you wear your headband.Tip: If your hair does bunch up, just take your headband off and put it back on again. This will smooth out any flyaways. You can also spray the top of your hair with a thin layer of hairspray to prevent flyaways. Creating a Half-Up Style Separate the hair on the crown of your head with a clip. Pull back the top part of your hair just above your ears like you normally would to put your hair half-up. Put this hair into a loose bun and secure it back with a large hair clip. You can leave some hair hanging over your ears if you’d like to. Wrap the headband over your forehead and back of your head. Pick up your headband and put it on your head how you normally would with the front over your forehead and the back resting against the base of your skull. Be careful around the hair clip in your hair and try not to disturb anything that’s tied up. Knitted headbands have a tendency to catch on pointy ends. Use caution around your hair clip so that you don’t rip or stretch out your headband. Let your hair down from the clip. Make sure your hair falls how it naturally would over the back of your head. Use your fingers to separate any clumps of hair that may be there after using the clip. You can also switch out your clip for some bobby pins and leave half of your hair pinned up if you’d prefer. Adjust your hair until it falls naturally over the headband. Use your fingers or a wide-toothed comb to push your hair forward towards your face over the headband. Use a mirror to look at the back of your head to check for lumps or bumps. This should create a seamless look that hides the back of the headband underneath your hair.Tip: If you did not pull enough hair back with your clip, it may bump out awkwardly over your headband. If it does, just take the headband off and start over with more hair pinned up on top. Doing a Ponytail or Bun Place the headband over your head and around your neck. It’s much easier to complete this look when the headband is already up over your head. Before you touch your hair, pull the headband up and over your head so that it is resting around your neck. Pull all of your hair up into a ponytail or bun with a hair tie. Use your fingers to rake your hair back to the crown of your head. Secure your hair at the top of your head with a hair tie in a messy bun or a ponytail.Tip: Don’t use a brush to rake back your hair before you put it up. This hairstyle is supposed to look a little bit messy. Move the headband up over your ears and around the back of your head. Grab the headband from around your neck and scoot it upward until it sits how you would normally wear it. Make sure that your hair is up high enough that it goes over the back of the headband. If your hair isn’t up high enough, you may not be able to see it behind the headband. Grab some pieces of hair from underneath the headband to frame your face. If you’d like a little bit more face framing, reach up under your headband and grab a few strands of hair in front of your ears on either side. Pull them out from underneath the headband so that they hang down and frame your face. This works well with the “messy” vibe of the overall hairstyle.
